STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 29, 2023
Frederick Walraven
ENNIS CENTER FOR CHILDREN - SAGINAW
3095 CABARET TRL S,
SAGINAW, MI, 48603-2284
Re: License #: CB730410102
SIR# 2023C0000582
Dear Frederick Walraven:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT

SAGINAW

SAGINAW, MI 48603-2284
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 06/08/2024

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12325 License recommendation.
Section (1) An agency shall recommend to the department the appropriate
Description licensing action consistent with facts contained in the foster home
evaluation and any special evaluations.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Special Evaluation was complete, but the findings of fact were
inappropriate. Foster mother's boyfriend vaped marijuana in the
house and gave vape remnants to youth's friend. Foster mother's
boyfriend permitted youth to use marijuana in the garage. Foster
home was found in full compliance.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Chief Administrator - On 7/14/2023 a meeting was held with
Chief Administrator via Microsoft Teams to discuss the
allegations. During the meeting, Chief Administrator’s questions
about the investigation process were answered. Chief
Administrator was also provided clarification that licensing staff
can find non-compliance with licensing rules despite DHHS staff
investigations resulting in no findings as the different workers are
investigating different allegations such as abuse/neglect vs.
licensing rules. He expressed concern that doing so made the
agency appear too harsh.
Licensing Worker - On 7/14/2023 an interview of Licensing
Worker was completed via Microsoft Teams. Licensing Worker
reported Foster Parent 2 never stated he allowed the youth to
smoke marijuana in the garage. When he was asked the question
directly, he responded that the youth was not allowed to smoke in
the house, rather he had to go outside or elsewhere. Licensing
Worker stated it does not appear in the report that Foster Parent 2
was asked specifically about allowing the youth to smoke in the
garage or that he denied doing so. Licensing Worker reported,
when interviewed by Licensing Worker, Adoption Worker stated
Foster Parent 1 allowed the youth to smoke marijuana in the
garage; however, Licensing Worker believes this statement was
made after the incident being investigated occurred and Adoption
Worker knew the youth had smoked in the garage. Licensing
Worker stated she believes the foster parents are not in violation
of rule 400.9201(1)(j) because they were utilizing the tools they
2

were given and following foster care’s guidance regarding the
youth’s marijuana use; however, foster care’s guidance to the
family is not documented in the report.
Licensing Worker reported the three youths who reported Foster
Parent 2 provided them with marijuana all provided different
stories. One youth stated all three youths were allowed to use
Foster Parent 2’s marijuana pen, one youth stated Foster Parent 2
gave him a marijuana cartridge to use in his own pen, and one
youth stated Foster Parent 2 did not allow any of the youths to use
the pen or cartridge. Licensing Worker stated she did not ask
Foster Parent 2 about the cartridge allegation and only asked two
of the boys specifically about the cartridge since the stories of the
three youths did not match. She reported one of the youths later
stated he had lied about using Foster Parent 2’s cartridge;
however, that information was not included in the report.
Licensing Supervisor - On 7/14/2023 an interview of Licensing
Supervisor was completed via Microsoft Teams. Licensing
Supervisor reported she believes Foster Parent 2 was including
the home’s garage when he stated he did not allow youth to
smoke in the home as the garage is attached to the home, which
is why that information wasn’t included in the report. She also
believes when Adoption Worker stated Foster Parent 1 allowed
the youth to smoke in the garage, she meant the youth had
smoked in the garage and Foster Parent 1 was aware it happened
after the fact. Licensing Supervisor reported the word “allowed”
was likely used incorrectly and could have been further assessed.
Licensing Supervisor stated she believes the foster parents are
not in violation of rule 400.9201(1)(j) because they were doing the
best they could with a difficult youth with substance abuse
concerns. She reported the foster parents were following guidance
given to them by the foster care worker and did demonstrate
responsible character, suitability, and ability to meet the needs of
children and provide for their care, supervision, and protection.
Licensing Supervisor stated that the guidance given by foster care
was not included in the report because she did not know that
details of a youth’s treatment plan could be included.
Licensing Supervisor reported the allegations made by the youths
regarding Foster Parent 2 providing them with a marijuana pen or
cartridge were not consistent which is why it was not assessed
further.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
3

Special Evaluation Report 2023C0000425 completed by Licensing
Worker and approved by Licensing Supervisor, which documented
the following:
• Foster Parent 1 stated that Youth A is a teenager, and he
will use marijuana if he wants to so she asked that he not
use marijuana in her home. Foster Parent 1 stated he could
go for a walk, be outside or somewhere else but not in her
home while using marijuana.
• Foster Parent 2 stated when all of the boys were in the
house, he had talked to them about not smoking in the
home and would appreciate if they would smoke outside.
Foster Parent 2 stated the next morning the garage smelled
like marijuana.
• Youth B stated that Foster Parent 2 talked to the boys and
said, "Foster Parent 1 doesn't like smoking in the house so
do it in the garage."
• Youth A stated he was asked not to use marijuana but was
told he could smoke marijuana in the garage. Youth A
stated Foster Parent 2 knows Foster Parent 1 doesn't want
marijuana in the house and allowed Youth A to smoke in
the garage.
• Adoption Worker stated Foster Parent 1 had mentioned
Youth A not being allowed to smoke marijuana in the house
but has allowed him to smoke marijuana in the garage.
• Youth A stated Foster Parent 1 provide all 3 boys a
marijuana pen when they were in the basement.
• Youth B stated Foster Parent 2 allowed Youth B to have
what was left in the cartridge that clicks into the marijuana
pen.
• Youth C stated he saw Foster Parent 2 in the basement
with a marijuana pen that he was consistently hitting.
Youth C said Foster Parent 2 wouldn't give the youths the
marijuana pen.
• Foster Parent 2 stated he did not give any of the children in
the home a marijuana pen. Foster Parent 2 stated he has not
used a nicotine pen or marijuana pen in over a year.
• Based on the interviews on 3/9/2023, 3/21/2023, and
4/4/2023 and the report written by a DHHS worker, Foster
Parent 1 & Foster Parent 2 are not in violation of Rule
400.9201(1)(j). Foster Parent 2 reported each incident in a
timely manner to foster care and intervened in the ways
that were recommended by foster care. The DHHS worker
recommended substantiation for Foster Parent 2’s
involvement in the allegations based on the disclosures
4

from the children in the home. The DHHS supervisor
denied substantiation.
Analysis The agency is found in violation as the facts contained in the
special evaluation report do not support the findings. The report
documents allegations by youths and the family’s adoption worker
that the foster parents allowed the youths to smoke marijuana in
the garage. There is no documentation that the foster parents
denied this allegation; however, the family was found in
compliance. The foster parents reported they told the youths if
they were going to smoke marijuana, to not do it in the home.
There is no documentation that the foster parents discouraged
marijuana use by the youths. Additionally, one youth alleged that
Foster Parent 2 provided him with a marijuana cartridge; however,
there is no documentation that anyone denied this allegation.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
Section (1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
Description agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(c) Conduct a thorough investigation including all necessary
collateral contacts.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation During the investigation an allegation was made that Caregiver 2
was smoking/vaping in the home which was not assessed.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Licensing Worker - On 7/14/2023 an interview of Licensing
Worker was completed via Microsoft Teams. Licensing Worker
reported rule 400.9310(1) was not assessed in the report as an
additional allegation because there no evidence that Foster Parent
2 smoked/vaped, despite allegation made by youths that they saw
him hitting a marijuana pen. Licensing Worker stated Foster
Parent 2 submitted to a drug screen for which he tested negative
for marijuana; however, that was not documented in the report.
She stated she did ask all youth residing in the home if they had
seen anyone smoke in the home; however, that was not
documented in the report.
Licensing Supervisor - On 7/14/2023 an interview of Licensing
Supervisor was completed via Microsoft Teams. Licensing
Supervisor reported rule 400.9310(1) was not included in the
report as an additional allegation. She reported she did not even
think about adding this as an allegation since she knew that no
one in the home smoked due to previous interaction with the
5

foster family, but she understands this should have been
assessed and included.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
Special Evaluation Report 2023C0000425 completed by Licensing
Worker and approved by Licensing Supervisor, which documented
the following:
• Youth C stated he saw Foster Parent 2 in the basement with a
marijuana pen that he was consistently hitting.
Analysis The agency is found in violation due to an additional allegation
made during the course of the special evaluation not being
investigated or documented.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of
Section conditions, books, records, and reports; access by
Description department, bureau of fire services, or local authorities;
records; report; forms; confidentiality; disclosure of
information; availability of confidential records; child
information cards to be provided to department; failure of
licensee to cooperate with investigation, inspection, or
examination.
Sec. 10.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department prescribes
regarding each child in its control and care and shall report to the
department, if requested, the facts the department requires with
reference to the children upon forms furnished by the department.
Except as otherwise provided in this subsection and subsection
(4), records regarding children and facts compiled about children
and their parents and relatives are confidential and disclosure of
this information must be properly safeguarded by the childcare
organization, the department, and any other entity in possession of
the information.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Confidential information appears in the special evaluation report.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Licensing Worker - On 7/14/2023 an interview of Licensing
Worker was completed via Microsoft Teams. Licensing Worker
reported she was supposed to remove the confidential information
6

during edits; however, she submitted the final report without
making that edit.
Licensing Supervisor - On 7/14/2023 an interview of Licensing
Supervisor was completed via Microsoft Teams. Licensing
Supervisor reported she did not notice that confidential information
was still in the report when she approved the final copy.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
Special Evaluation Report 2023C0000425 completed by Licensing
Worker and approved by Licensing Supervisor, which documented
the involvement of CPS-MIC in the investigation.
Analysis The agency is found in violation as confidential information in
located within the special evaluation report.
Conclusion Violation Established
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical Assistance is being provided regarding visits with secondary caregivers.
The special evaluation report documents that Foster Parent 2 had never been seen
in person by the assigned foster care worker throughout Youth A’s placement in the
home. MDHHS Foster Care Policy requires that secondary caregivers be seen
during the assigned foster care worker’s monthly home visits with the youth and
caregivers at least quarterly.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
August 28, 2023
______________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 28, 2023
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
